# Accounting Standards Codification

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

Jump to navigation Jump to search

[![Stub icon](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8b/Accountancy_template.svg/40px-Accountancy_template.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Accountancy_template.svg) | _This[accounting](/wiki/Accounting "Accounting")-related article is a [stub](/wiki/Wikipedia:Stub "Wikipedia:Stub"). You can help Wikipedia by [expanding it](//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Accounting_Standards_Codification&action=edit)._

  * [v](/wiki/Template:Accounting-stub "Template:Accounting-stub")
  * [t](/wiki/Template_talk:Accounting-stub "Template talk:Accounting-stub")
  * [e](//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Template:Accounting-stub&action=edit)

  
---|---  
  
In [US](/wiki/US "US") [accounting](/wiki/Accounting "Accounting") practices,
the Accounting Standards Codification is the current single source of United
States [Generally Accepted Accounting
Principles](/wiki/Generally_Accepted_Accounting_Principles "Generally Accepted
Accounting Principles") (GAAP). It is maintained by the [Financial Accounting
Standards Board](/wiki/Financial_Accounting_Standards_Board "Financial
Accounting Standards Board") (FASB).

## Contents

[hide]

  * 1 FASB accounting standards codification
  * 2 Goal
  * 3 Leading up to the codification process
  * 4 Public access to codification
  * 5 Structure
  * 6 See also
  * 7 References
  * 8 External links

## FASB accounting standards
codification[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Accounting_Standards_Codification&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: FASB accounting standards codification")]

The codification is effective for interim and annual periods ending after
September 15, 2009. All prior accounting standards documents were superseded
as described in FASB Statement No. 168, The FASB Accounting Standards
Codification and the Hierarchy of Generally Accepted Accounting Principles.
Accounting literature not included in the Codification is non-authoritative.

The Codification reorganizes the thousands of U.S. GAAP pronouncements into
roughly 90 accounting topics and displays all topics using a consistent
structure. It also includes relevant [U.S. Securities and Exchange
Commission](/wiki/U.S._Securities_and_Exchange_Commission "U.S. Securities and
Exchange Commission") (SEC) guidance that follows the same topical structure
in separate sections in the Codification.

To prepare constituents for the change, the FASB provided a number of tools
and training resources.[1]

The Codification did not change GAAP, but it introduced a new structure,
organized in an easily accessible, user-friendly online research system. The
FASB expected the system to reduce the amount of time and effort required to
research accounting issues, mitigate the risk of noncompliance with standards
through improved usability of the literature, provide accurate information
with real-time updates as new standards are released, and assist the FASB with
the research efforts required during the standard-setting process.[2]

##
Goal[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Accounting_Standards_Codification&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: Goal")]

The three primary goals of the codification are "simplify user access by
codifying all authoritative U.S. GAAP in one spot, ensure that the
codification content accurately represented authoritative U.S. GAAP as of July
1, 2009, and to create a codification research system that is up to date for
the released results of standard-setting activity."[2] The codification was
made to make accounting standards easier to find through a single data base.

## Leading up to the codification
process[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Accounting_Standards_Codification&action=edit&section=3
"Edit section: Leading up to the codification process")]

Before the Codification, accounting standards lacked a consistent and logical
structure. For the last 50 years, U.S. GAAP consisted of thousands of
standards with multiple standard setters. The old U.S. GAAP were difficult to
interpret, and the complexity of the standards made it hard for users to stay
up to date. Problems with the old standards increased financial reporting risk
and led to inefficiencies that increased cost. FASAC then voiced its concerns
due to the increase of financial reporting guidance from the old U.S. GAAP
standards, and the FASB responded by launching a new project to codify the
standards. The project was approved in September 2004 by the Trustees of the
Financial Accounting Foundation.[2]

## Public access to
codification[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Accounting_Standards_Codification&action=edit&section=4
"Edit section: Public access to codification")]

All users must register to view any codification information. The codification
allows a free basic view or paid professional view to the public. The
professional view requires an annual subcription up to $940 depending on
concurrent users. [3] Discounts may apply to multiple concurrent users. [4]The
codification is used by accounting and reporting professionals, analysts and
investors.

##
Structure[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Accounting_Standards_Codification&action=edit&section=5
"Edit section: Structure")]

Each ASC reference is structured as a series of four numbers separated by
hyphens: a three-digit Topic (the first digit of which represents an Area), a
two-digit Subtopic, a two-digit Section, and a two- or three-digit Paragraph.
[5]

Topic Series | Area  
---|---  
100 | General Principles  
200 | Presentation  
300 | Assets  
400 | Liabilities  
500 | Equity  
600 | Revenue  
700 | Expenses  
800 | Broad Transactions  
900 | Industry  
  
Subtopic 10 is always "Overall."

Section numbers are standardized across topics (not all subtopics have all
sections):

Section number | Section title  
---|---  
00 | Status  
05 | Overview and Background  
10 | Objectives  
15 | Scope and Scope Exceptions  
20 | Glossary  
25 | Recognition  
30 | Initial Measurement  
35 | Subsequent Measurement  
40 | Derecognition  
45 | Other Presentation Matters  
50 | Disclosure  
55 | Implementation Guidance and Illustrations  
60 | Relationships  
65 | Transition and Open Effective Date Information  
70 | Grandfathered Guidance  
75 | XBRL Elements  
  
For instance, 210-10-20 is Balance Sheet, Overall, Glossary. 605-40-25-1 is
Revenue Recognition, Gains and Losses, Recognition, first paragraph.

## See
also[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Accounting_Standards_Codification&action=edit&section=6
"Edit section: See also")]

  2. ^ Jump up to: _**a**_ _**b**_ _**c**_ ["FASB Accounting Standards CodificationTM Notice to Constituents (v 2.0)"](https://asc.fasb.org/imageRoot/63/6537863.pdf) (PDF). _Financial Accounting Standards Board_. Jul 1, 2009. Retrieved Oct 21, 2017.

qa.question: when did fasb codification become authoritative u.s. gaap

nq_212_2.Query Analysis: The query asks for the date when the FASB Codification became authoritative U.S. GAAP.
nq_212_2.Query Keywords Extraction: FASB Codification, authoritative, U.S. GAAP, date
nq_212_2.Answer Analysis: The answer indicates that the FASB Codification became authoritative after September 15, 2009.
nq_212_2.Document Content Analysis: The document discusses the FASB Codification, its goals, and the changes it introduced to U.S. GAAP. It mentions that the codification was made to simplify user access and ensure accuracy as of July 1, 2009, but does not explicitly state when it became authoritative.
nq_212_2.Document and Query Keywords Matching: The document includes keywords such as 'FASB', 'Codification', and 'U.S. GAAP'.
nq_212_2.Document and Answer Keywords Matching: The document does not explicitly mention 'after September 15, 2009'.
nq_212_2.Key Information Matching: The document provides context about the codification and its goals, including a reference to July 1, 2009, but lacks the specific date when it became authoritative.
nq_212_2.Can the Document Answer the Query: No, the document does not provide the exact date when the FASB Codification became authoritative.
nq_212_2.Can the Document Help Infer Additional I: Yes, the document provides background information about the codification process and its significance, which can help understand the context around the query.
nq_212_2.Explanation: The document is partially relevant as it provides context and background information about the FASB Codification and its goals, but it does not directly answer the specific question about the date it became authoritative. The mention of July 1, 2009, as a key date for the codification's accuracy suggests proximity to the answer but does not confirm the exact date of authority.

nq_282152_2.Key Information Matching: While the document mentions FASB and U.S. GAAP, it does not provide any information directly related to the codification becoming authoritative.

nq_282152_2.Can the Document Help Infer Additional I: No, the document does not contain any information that would help infer the date when the FASB codification became authoritative.
nq_282152_2.Explanation: The document is not relevant to the query as it does not provide any information about the FASB codification becoming authoritative. It focuses on the going concern assumption and related auditing standards, which are tangential to the specific query about the FASB codification's authoritative status.

nq_212_1.Query Analysis: The query asks for the date when the FASB Codification became authoritative as U.S. GAAP.
nq_212_1.Query Keywords Extraction: FASB Codification, authoritative, U.S. GAAP, date
nq_212_1.Answer Analysis: The answer indicates that the FASB Codification became authoritative after September 15, 2009.

It mentions that the codification is effective for interim and annual periods ending after September 15, 2009, and that all prior accounting standards documents were superseded by this codification.
nq_212_1.Document and Query Keywords Matching: The document includes 'FASB Codification', 'authoritative', and 'U.S. GAAP'.
nq_212_1.Document and Answer Keywords Matching: The document explicitly mentions 'after September 15, 2009', which matches the answer.
nq_212_1.Key Information Matching: The document directly states the date when the FASB Codification became effective, which is the key information needed to answer the query.
nq_212_1.Can the Document Answer the Query: Yes, the document directly answers the query by stating the date when the FASB Codification became authoritative.
nq_212_1.Can the Document Help Infer Additional I: Yes, the document provides additional context about the codification process and its impact on U.S. GAAP.
nq_212_1.Explanation: The document is directly related to the query and provides the exact information needed to answer it. It not only states the date when the FASB Codification became authoritative but also offers additional context about the codification's structure and impact, enhancing the understanding of the topic.
